div1.head: Jim to Paul May 27th ‘15
div1.p: Here’s how and hoping that everything’s sunny again. Hope your brother is walking around now and that your fiancee is looking in shop windows for new things for her trousseau.

I’m sorry to have to report that Thierry-Delanoue [sp?] the Vicomte’s friend got wounded in yesterday’s bombardment. Twenty people, mostly women and children were killed and thirty five wounded. I had the pleasant task of gathering up some of the dead. It was horrible. In one shop, where I had
gotten some cakes in the morning, the Madame and her daughter lay dead. They were frightfully mangled. One eye hung out over the bleeding, butchered face and I’ll never forget the wild look of fear expressed in the dead orb. All down the main street were pools of blood; shattered glass littered the streets and the debris of buildings blocked the way. When we got to a hospital with our first load we were directed to a long semi circular cellar and carried the dead down there. As far as one could see were groaning wounded. Nurses
were bending over them and in the dim light given off by the candles we noticed relatives crying over the wounded that were unconscious. In one store we had to break a window and pull the dead thru [sic] it which was a nasty job. On the next trip to the hospital I saw an old old man supporting his daughter that had been hit and whose wounds were dressed. Very slowly the old man and the little girl in her white pinafore walked down the street towards their home. The old fellow was very grave and the
child was trying her best not to cry. That impressed me as the saddest thing I’d seen. I don’t know why. Immediately afterwards I left for a station back of the trenches to take up my night duty and tho [sic] a shell cam down there and killed some soldiers that didn’t seem horrible. It was in the military atmosphere. Guns and caissons were about and soldiers were going and returning from the trenches. It seemed part of the game up there and didn’t appear shocking. In the town; in the middle of civil pursuits to see the citizens dead and their
blood staining the sidewalks was a terrible thing. People are rapidly evacuating the town and it is really what should have been done months ago.

A German deserter tells us the Boches have 30,000 shells to let fly into our town before they are pushed out of range. That will do considerable smearing up of the place. One cannot believe all the wild stories going around of course. Why one rumor “from a most reliable source” had it that our caserne was to be
smeared off the globe at 11:30 a.m. yesterday.

Nice, cheerful letter I’ve written you. Excuse me. By the way, to turn to more interesting things, I saw three hundred Greek volunteers arrive at a point below here the other day. Premier Etranger outfit—new batch— I understand. One of em [sic] said he’d been in New York. “For twoa [sic] year I sella [sic] da [sic] banan [sic].” Great old mob you meet over here, Mon brave.
